title: Communication Skills - Persuasion and Motivation
headline: Enhance your communication skills by learning the theories behind persuasion and motivation with this course.
description: This free online communication skills course focuses on persuasion and motivation. It will introduce you to the art of persuasion and teach you motivation techniques useful in any situation. Persuasion impacts our daily lives and differs from manipulation. With this course, you will learn their differences as well as look into brainwashing and Stockholm syndrome. You will also study different motivation theories, and more!
courseDescription:
This course begins by discussing the role of communication and its relationship with the art of persuasion. You will study the five-factor model for examining human personality as well as learn different negotiation techniques effective for reaching mutually satisfactory agreements between parties. You will look into what makes persuasion different from manipulation as well as study the factors that influence attitudes and messages. In addition, you will study the use of fear appeal and the process of negotiation.

You will then look into the relationship between motivation and achieving goals. Motivation relates to the force, stimulus, or influence that guides people to do the things they do. It is the call for action or behavior, moving the self to obtain pleasure and avoid pain. With this course, you will learn the theories surrounding motivation and the ways to help increase an individualâ€™s motivation. In addition, you will also look into the relationship between leadership and motivation as well as how a person can be a good leader.

Improving your persuasion and motivation skills can do you a lot of good. Upon the completion of this course, you will learn motivation techniques that will give your behavior its much-needed energy and direction which is useful not just in your personal life but more importantly for your career. You will also learn motivation theories applicable to any leadership role. Check out this course and start developing your communication and motivation skills now!

• The key points from this module are:
  • Research shows that up to 90% of people think that they can judge someoneâ€™s personality just by looking at their face.
    Scientists are uncovering evidence that some personality traits may be written on our faces.
     
    Five-factor model for examining human personality
    The most widely accepted model for examining human personality is the five-factor model. 
    The five-factor model consists of openness to experience, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism.

    â€¢ Openness to experience: creative, original, independent.
    â€¢ Conscientiousness: careful, hard-working, conscientious.
    â€¢ Extraversion: affectionate, talkative, sociable.
    â€¢ Agreeableness: forgiving, sympathetic, warm.
    â€¢ Neuroticism: nervous, worrying, highly strung. Faces are unpredictable. Despite recent research.

    Persuasion versus Manipulation
    Persuasion is an important part of our everyday lives; it is pervasive across all areas. 
    The most persuasive person in the family is often the child, because they donâ€™t adhere to rules are always interested in new things.
    Everyone thinks that they are intelligent enough to see through persuasion and know the truth, this is a misleading thought as they are persuaded everyday through new information or advice. 
    Persuasion can be seen throughout history; for example, politicians. 
    Manipulation takes place throughout our lives, and is when persuasion is dishonest or intent to hurt. 
    Manipulation is a subset of persuasion, and is usually temporary because it is not true. 
    The intent of the person who is persuading/manipulating is key; if the intent is to deceive or hurt then persuasion becomes manipulation. Brainwashing is usually a combination of persuasion, coercion and repetition and so is considered manipulation.

• The key points from this module are:
  • Motivation
    Motivation relates to the force, stimulus, or influence that guides people to do the things they do.
    Motivation is the call for action or behaviour; moving the self the obtain pleasure and avoid pain. 
    There are three components of motivation; Direction, effort and persistence.
    Direction refers to what the person is trying to do. 
    Effort refers to how hard a person is working to achieve it. 
    Persistence refers to how long a person continues to do it. 

    The motivational process
    The first step of the motivational process is needs, drives, and expectations. These can be physiological or social. 
    The second step of the motivational process is tension. 
    The third step of the motivational process is overt/covert behaviour. 
    The fourth step of the motivational process is the goal.
    The fifth step of the motivational process is tension reduction and satisfaction.
    In some cases, a barrier can emerge between the behaviour and the goal which prevents the individual from reaching the goal. 
    Some people who encounter failures become frustrated, defensive, and make-up excuses. This is called dysfunctional coping. 
    Other individuals keep trying until they succeed. This is called functional coping. 
    Motivation is a psychological force that contributes to a person's degree of commitment. It includes drives and desires for goal attainment that regulate the direction, intensity, and persistence of human action.

    Desires and drives cause behaviour, but they may be the the result of behaviour. For example, a person's desire for accomplishment may be made keener by the satisfaction from achieving a preferred goal or it may be dulled by failure.
